questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the dermatology OPD with lesions on her cheeks that aggravate when exposed to sunlight, as shown in the image below. She has also had fatigue, myalgias, and arthralgias over the past four months. What would be the expected finding on direct immunofluorescence of a skin biopsy of a lesion from this patient?

choices.text: Granular continuous deposit of IgG and C3 in the dermo-epidermal junction
Linear IgG and C3 deposits along the basement membrane zone
Intercellular IgG and C3 deposits in the epidermis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Granular continuous deposits of IgG and C3 in the dermo-epidermal junction

 

Explanation:

 

Based on the clinical presentation described, with a typical “malar rash/butterfly rash” aggravated by sunlight exposure along with systemic symptoms such as fatigue, myalgias, and arthralgias, the patient likely has systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

Malar rash with sparing of nasolabial folds.

 

 

  • The lupus band test (LBT) is a diagnostic tool where immunofluorescence reveals homogenous deposits along the dermo-epidermal junction.
  • These deposits contain
    • Predominantly IgG, but also occasionally IgM and IgA,
    • Complement components (C1q, C3)
  • Present both in lesions and normal skin.
  • Present in 80% of patients with SLE and DLE.

 

Option

Direct Immunofluorescence Test - Image

Linear IgG and C3 deposits along the BMZ (Option B) :

 

  • Also known as shoreline fluorescence pattern
  • Seen in bullous pemphigoid and epidermolysis bullosa

Granular IgA in dermal papillae (Option C):

 
  • Papillary tip immunofluorescence is seen in dermatitis herpetiformis

Intercellular IgG and C3 deposits in the epidermis (Option D):

  • Characteristic fish-net pattern of immunofluorescence is seen in pemphigous vulgaris

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presented with complaints of a circular, scaly rash on her scalp, as shown in the image. On examination, you notice multiple small spikes over the underside of the rash. This presentation is most characteristic of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Discoid lupus erythematosus

Explanation: ‘Carpet tack sign,’ as shown in the image, is seen in discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE). Scales on the undersurface of the lesion appear like tin tacks penetrated on carpets.

Discoid lupus erythematosus is the most common type of chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus.

Clinical features:

 

  • Localized Skin Involvement: Predominantly affects the face and scalp, presenting as circumscribed/ discoid erythematous patches on cheeks, nose bridge, ears, neck, and scalp

  • Lesions exhibit adherent scale with underlying horny plugs (“tin-tack” sign) due to follicular plugging.
  • Characterized by three zones:
    • Central Atrophy area
    • Middle activity - perifollicular plugging, scaling, telangiectasias
    • Zone of hyperpigmentation
  • Schuster sign: Lesions over the ear conchae

  • Cicatricial alopecia
  • Scarring and pigmentary changes: Scarring (atrophic, hypertrophic, cribriform) is common. Hyper/Hypo pigmentation is also seen, especially in dark-skinned individuals.

Incorrect options explanation:

Option A: Psoriasis typically presents with silvery scales and found on the extensor surface such as elbow and knees

Option B: Seborrheic dermatitis presents with greasy scales and erythema affecting scalp, eyebrows and nasolabial folds.

Option C: Rosacea is characterized by facial erythema, telangiectasia, but not with scaly plaques

questions.text: A 3-week-old neonate is brought to the dermatology OPD with facial rashes exacerbated by sunlight exposure. Examination reveals erythematous, scaly papules around the eyes as shown in the image below. Maternal history includes positive anti-Ro/SSA antibodies. Which congenital cardiac anomaly is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer a. Heart block

 

Explanation:

  • A neonate presenting with facial rashes exacerbated by sunlight exposure, along with a maternal history of positive anti-Ro/SSA antibodies, is highly suggestive of neonatal lupus erythematosus (NLE).
  • NLE occurs when maternal autoantibodies, particularly anti-Ro/SSA antibodies, cross the placenta and affect the fetus.

Clinical features of Neonatal Lupus Erythematosus are:

  • Cutaneous: Rash resembling subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (SCLE) or discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE).
  • Owl’s eye sign or Racoon sign- Erythematous, slightly scaly eruption on the face and periorbital skin
  • Cardiac:
    • Various degrees of heart block, including first-degree, second-degree, or complete heart block.
    • A complete heart block may require pacemaker placement.
  • Hepatic involvement:
    • Hepatitis
    • cholestasis,
  • Hematological abnormalities:
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Anemia
  • Neurological manifestations:
    • seizures
    • Developmental delay.
  • Respiratory manifestations:
    • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)
    • Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN),

Anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies, also known as anti-SSA and anti-SSB antibodies are commonly implicated in neonatal systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and also Sjögren's syndrome.

 

Incorrect Answer Explanation

Option B: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is commonly seen in premature infants and is associated with conditions such as respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), and bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD).

 

Option C: Coarctation of the aorta can occur in the context of Turner syndrome.

 

Option D: Aortic stenosis occurs in Williams Syndrome (Chromosome 7 defect)

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman was recently diagnosed with cutaneous lupus erythematosus. During her review, she has come to you with a pamphlet and would like to discuss all her treatment options.

Which of the following drugs are not used for the treatment of cutaneous LE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A

Explanation: Leflunomide is an immunomodulatory drug that can cause drug-induced lupus erythematosus, and hence, it is contraindicated in the treatment of cutaneous LE.

  • It acts via the inhibition of dihydroorotate dehydrogenase.
  • It is used to treat rheumatoid and psoriatic arthritis.

 

Some of the most commonly implicated drugs in drug-induced LE (DILE) include:

  • Procainamide
  • Hydralazine
  • Isoniazid
  • Minocycline
  • Quinidine
  • Anti-TNF agents (e.g., infliximab, adalimumab)
  • Methyldopa
  • Propylthiouracil
  • TNF-α inhibitors

 

Usually, withdrawal of causative drug resolves the disease

Positive anti-histone antibodies are particularly specific for DILE

 

Incorrect options explanation:

Option b. Corticosteroids: These are the preferred first-line drugs for cutaneous lupus erythematosus due to their potent anti-inflammatory effect.

  • They can be applied topically or administered intralesionally.
  • Cutaneous atrophy is a common side effect of this drug, and the patient should be carefully instructed to limit the application over the skin only.

 

Option c. Photoprotection: UV radiation is directly responsible for inducing lesions and hence, should be avoided.

  • Sunscreens and protective clothing should be worn daily.
  • Photoprotection also includes avoiding drugs that cause photosensitivity (e.g., Tetracyclines, Metformin, Hydrochlorothiazides, sulfonamides, etc.)

 

Option d. Chloroquine: Antimalarial agents like chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine agents for cutaneous lupus.

  • These drugs have an immune-modulating and photoprotective effect.
  • Ocular toxicity, specifically retinopathy, is a common side effect

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man was recently diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the lung and started chemotherapy. During a follow-up visit, he complained of rashes over his face and hands, as shown in the image. He also reports fatigue and weakness in his legs while climbing stairs.



     



What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer b. Dermatomyositis

 

Explanation:

  • The presence of limb weakness and cutaneous manifestations in association with a malignancy indicate a diagnosis of dermatomyositis.
  • Inflammatory myopathies like dermatomyositis have an association with malignancies such as ovarian, lung, gastrointestinal, and breast cancer.

 

Dermatomyositis is a chronic, inflammatory myositis seen in adults around 50-60 years of age.

 

Clinical features

  • It presents as symmetrical muscle weakness (proximal > distal)
  • Gottron’s papules (erythematous scaly papules over knuckles) are pathognomonic of the disease.

  • Gottron’s sign: Symmetric, confluent, violaceous macular erythema (CMVE) on the back of fingers (interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints) , on the extensor surfaces of joints of the elbows, knees, or ankles.

  • CMVE is seen over other sites too, and is named accordingly.
    • Heliotrope rash: CMVE over the periorbital skin
    • V-Sign: CMVE over the anterior aspect of the neck
    • Shawl sign: Involvement of upper back
    • Holster sign: Rash over the lateral aspect of the thigh
    • Mechanic’s hand: Hyperkeratosis and fissuring on the edges of the fingers.

               

   ​​​​

          Holtser Sign

     

      Mechanics Hands

 

      Shawl Sign 

              

 

 

Polymyositis (Option A): Differences between dermatomyositis and polymyositis are as follows:

 

Dermatomyositis

Polymyositis

Skin Involvement

Present

Typically lacks characteristic skin manifestations

Associated Conditions

More frequently associated with malignancies

Less frequently associated with malignancies

Muscle Biopsy Findings

May show perifascicular atrophy pattern

Typically shows endomysial inflammation pattern

 

Lambert-Eaton syndrome (Option C) is a neuromuscular disorder that presents with proximal muscle weakness but no cutaneous manifestations, it is also associated with adenocarcinoma of the lung. Unlike dermatomyositis, deep tendon reflexes are lost in this syndrome.

 

Drug reaction (Option D): Acute presentation of generalized urticaria/ drug reaction does not present with characteristic features of Grotton’s papules and the V- Sign.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old women comes to your OPD with her mother due to  depressed linear lesion associated with hair loss on scalp for the past 3 years. She also has an area of progressive hypopigmentation and hair loss in her scalp as shown in the image below.



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C

Explanation:

  • "En coup de sabre" is a French term meaning "struck by the sword." It refers to a specific subtype of localized scleroderma called morphea, characterized by excessive collagen deposition leading to thickening and hardening of the skin and underlying tissues.
  • This linear lesion typically extends vertically from the hairline downward, resembling a stroke from a sabre or sword.
  • It may vary in width and depth and often results in a visible depression or indentation in the skin. This may resemble the appearance of the fictional character "Kakashi Hatake" from the anime series Naruto, who has a similar linear scar on his forehead.

Scleroderma is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by excessive collagen production, leading to the thickening and hardening of the skin and other connective tissues

 

The types of scleroderma are described below,

  • Localized Scleroderma: This type of scleroderma primarily affects the skin and underlying tissues in specific areas of the body.
    • Morphea
    • Linear Scleroderma
    • En coup de sabre alopecia.

 

  • Systemic Sclerosis (Systemic Scleroderma): Systemic sclerosis is a more severe form of scleroderma that not only affects the skin but also involves internal organs such as the lungs, heart, kidneys, and gastrointestinal tract.
    • Limited Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis (lcSSc)
    • Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis (dcSSc)

Incorrect Options

Option A: Atrophic scar usually occurs following injury or surgery, which is not present in this patient.

 

Option B: Gottron’s papules are raised, violaceous to erythematous lesions typically found over the extensor surfaces of the joints, such as the knuckles, elbows, and knees in dermatomyositis.

 

Option D: Rowell syndrome, also known as lupus erythematosus overlap syndrome, is a rare condition characterized by features of both systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and erythema multiforme

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man with interstitial lung disease presents to you with complaints of a lesion over his chest.

On examination, you notice the skin proximal to MCP joints appears thickened. There are also small ulcers over his fingertips.

 



 

Which of the following would be the most specific investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A

 

Explanation:

  • Anti-topoisomerase I antibody, also known as anti-Scl-70 antibody, is positive in systemic sclerosis. It is part of the diagnostic criteria for systemic sclerosis.
  • The image depicts the ‘salt and pepper appearance’ of skin seen in scleroderma
  • This in combination with a history of ILD, thickened skin proximal to MCP joints or sclerodactyly (see image), and digital tip ulcers indicates a diagnosis of scleroderma.

‘salt and pepper appearance’ of skin

thickened skin proximal to MCP joints or sclerodactyly

Mask-like face in scleroderma.

Other antibodies include: Anticentromere and Anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies

Option b. Anti-Ro (SS-A) antibodies: Most commonly positive in discoid lupus erythematosus, especially neonatal lupus.

 

Option c. Antisynthetase antibodies: Seen in Dermatomyositis

 

Option d. Antinuclear antibodies: Positive in multiple autoimmune connective tissue diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Sjogren's syndrome, and polymyositis/dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman complains that the tips of her fingers are changing from pale white to bluish-red during winter. She states that it started five years ago but has worsened recently, along with difficulty swallowing food. Which of the following findings would you also expect to find in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B

Explanation:

  • Cold-associated colour changes in the fingers, such as bluish-red discoloration, along with dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), are classic symptoms associated with Raynaud's phenomenon and oesophagal dysfunction, respectively, which are features of scleroderma. 

               

  • CREST syndrome is a type of limited scleroderma that consists of calcinosis cutis, Raynaud phenomenon, oesophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia
  • Calcinosis cutis, the deposition of calcium in the skin and subcutaneous tissues is a common complication of systemic sclerosis.

Von Kossa stain used for calcinosis cutis:

Pitted scar on fingertips in Raynaud's phenomenon:

 

 

Incorrect Options

 

A) Hypercalcemia: While hypercalcemia can occur in certain conditions, such as hyperparathyroidism or malignancies, it is not a characteristic feature of systemic sclerosis.

 

C) Malar Rash: A malar rash, a rash that appears on the cheeks and resembles a butterfly shape, is characteristic of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), not systemic sclerosis.

 

D) Morphea: Morphea, a localized form of scleroderma, primarily affects the skin and does not typically involve the oesophagus or cause dysphagia (systemic sclerosis)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a history of Raynaud’s phenomenon, arthritis, myalgia and fatigue. On examination, she has a rash on her face that spares her nasolabial folds. Her fingers appear puffy and sausage-shaped. Positive autoantibodies to anti-U1RNP along with her history are most indicative of which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B

Explanation:

  • Mixed connective tissue disease presents a combination of features of cutaneous LE, scleroderma, and dermatomyositis.
  • Anti-U1RNP antibody (anti-U1RNP) is a specific serological marker for mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD).
  • Mixed connective tissue disease is a type of overlap syndrome where one patient will have features of multiple connective tissue diseases.
  • Due to its non-specific presentation, autoantibody testing is fundamental.
  • Treatment:
    • First line: Corticosteroids show good response
    • Second line: Hydroxychloroquine and methotrexate

Incorrect options

Option a. Scleroderma: While scleroderma is associated with various autoantibodies, including anti-centromere antibodies and anti-topoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibodies, it is not typically associated with anti-U1 ribonucleoprotein antibodies. Scleroderma primarily presents with skin thickening, Raynaud phenomenon, and internal organ involvement.Malar rash is not a feature.

Option c. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (LE): Systemic lupus erythematosus is primarily associated with anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA - Most sensitive), anti-dsDNA antibodies, and anti-Smith (anti-Sm - Most specific) antibodies.

Option d. Dermatomyositis: Dermatomyositis is associated with various autoantibodies, including anti-Jo-1 antibodies and anti-Mi-2 antibodies. Dermatomyositis is characterized by muscle weakness and skin involvement, including a characteristic skin rash.
